div1.head: Mac. to Mon. Paul Rockwell Sept 4th 1916
div1.p: Thanks old pal for the long and enjoyable letter of Friday.
So you tracked down the famous Falconie. Sorry we won’t have a chance to realize on our investment before she goes to Madrid.
Heard from good, old Grundy. Hope Munsey has sense enough to keep him.

I’m very much better as far as the ball is concerned but my back has not improved to any marked degree. I get massages, but inspite [sic] of these the pain keeps on. The boss speaks of sending me to a hospital, God knows where. Its mighty kind of you to invite me to get well Chez vous and I appreciate it immensely — only it isn’t possible. They wouldn’t give me leave. I’ll probably see you tho [sic] for I’ll have to go thru [sic] Paris to rejoin escadrille which, as you know, is leaving Bar. Its the only route from here to northern points. Don’t mention this to our young lady friends for if I only have a day I would rather spend it with you and don’t want Marcelle et al to be offended. M
has been mighty nice — send me books and magazines but I have so much reading matter now I’m swamped.
All right, I’ll cook you up a letter on the depot d’eclope. Rather interesting I think too. Will have to wait until I’m sitting up.
By the time you get thru [sic] with me in the American papers I’ll have a line up a’ la Hobson.

Who are the two worthies that claim to have flown in France and who are now back in the states instructing eleve [sic] pilots and drawing down $150 per week? There’s a fake some place. Something ought to be done about it. One is Phil Rader I think. They say they served with France and are at Newport News training school. Go to it old hound.

I keep getting annoying letters from my mother asking me to consent to her obtaining a release for me and this last letter, which
gives me the dope on the two above mentioned lads, asks me to cable. She sent me a check which she insists on my keeping, so I guess I’ll have to cable. Will you please do it for me and I’ll pay you when I pass through. The cable goes to my brother in law, whose cable address is: Adfol Chicago
Just say: Letter received, will not contemplate release. Jim

Tell Marcelle she missed her greatest joy in life by not sleeping with the Russian. She would have had her extasy [sic], and then been disillusioned — so that she would have had no regrets at not marrying him.
Skipper, the good old soul has kept me posted re the doings of the crowd and has attended to my junk and the moving there of.

The concert Sunday was great. I was put in officers’ row. One chap, a soldier who was a singer and dancer at the Olympia got off a delightful ditty about
picking up a queen on his permission and getting a frightful and torturing dose. The doctor in Paris was for cutting off the tool but he returned an front and goes to a depot d’eclopes. There was a surprising amount of appreciative guffaws which would lead me to infer that several of the gentlemen here have had unwise love affairs.
I suppose Kiffin will be with you on the 6th. Give him my regards, and write soon — its a great cheer.
